cultural_note: The universal Moroccan greeting. Used at any time of day. Often followed by 'labas?' (how are you?).
From French 'la base'. Used both as a question and answer. 'Labas?' = 'Are you OK?' / 'Labas' = 'I'm fine'.

examples.english: Good morning, how are you doing?

cultural_note: Literally 'with peace'. The standard way to say goodbye in Morocco.
While 'merci' (French) is also widely used in Morocco, 'shukran' is the Darija/Arabic form.

examples.arabic: عافاك، عطيني واحد الكاس ديال أتاي
examples.english: Please, give me a glass of tea
examples.french: S'il te plaît, donne-moi un verre de thé

cultural_note: The Darija way to say please. More personal than the French 'sil vous plait' which is also used.
Literally 'no thanks needed for a duty'. The formal way to respond to thanks.
Used constantly in Morocco after any positive statement. Essential part of daily speech regardless of religiosity.

examples.arabic: غادي نمشي غدا، إن شاء الله
examples.french: J'irai demain, si Dieu le veut

cultural_note: Used for anything in the future. Can mean genuine hope, polite maybe, or even 'probably not'. Context is everything.
Said before eating, starting a journey, or any new activity. Also used to invite someone to eat.

examples.french: Dieu te bénisse, tu as grandi !

cultural_note: Used to express admiration while warding off the evil eye. Say it when you see something beautiful or impressive.

examples.english: That's enough, I don't want anymore
examples.french: C'est bon, je n'en veux plus

cultural_note: One of the most versatile words in Darija. Can mean 'OK', 'enough', 'done', 'stop', 'that's it', or 'alright'.
The Darija 'OK'. Also means 'even though' in some contexts. You'll hear this a hundred times a day.
Tag question added to the end of sentences. Like the French 'n'est-ce pas' or English 'right?'.
The Darija 'yes'. More casual than 'iyeh'. This is what you'll hear in daily conversation.

examples.english: My name is Karim, and you?
Nice to meet you, I'm from Marrakech

cultural_note: A more emotional 'please', invoking God's protection on the person. Used when you really need something.

examples.english: Thank you so much, God bless you
examples.french: Merci beaucoup, que Dieu te bénisse

cultural_note: The standard way to express gratitude beyond 'shukran'. Used after receiving help or a kind gesture.
Used to welcome someone. In Morocco, hospitality is sacred — you'll hear this a lot.

examples.english: Excuse me, where is the bathroom?

cultural_note: The Darija way to apologize or ask for pardon. 'Smh' comes from the root meaning 'to forgive'.

english: a lot / very much / too much
cultural_note: One of the most common Darija words. Used for emphasis. 'Shukran bzzaf' = thank you very much.

examples.french: Je parle un peu de Darija

cultural_note: Essential for softening requests or describing small amounts. 'Shwiya shwiya' means 'slowly, slowly'.

examples.english: Come on, we're going to be late!
examples.french: Allez, on va être en retard !

cultural_note: Used constantly to mean 'let's go', 'come on', 'hurry up', or to signal departure.

examples.english: How do I get to Jemaa el-Fna?

cultural_note: Essential for shopping in the souk. 'Bsh7al hada?' is the first phrase every tourist learns.

examples.english: I don't know, ask someone else
examples.french: Je ne sais pas, demande à quelqu'un d'autre

cultural_note: The Darija all-purpose positive adjective. Means good, nice, fine, beautiful, great.

examples.english: Give me a glass of tea

cultural_note: THE Moroccan drink. Prepared with Chinese gunpowder green tea, fresh spearmint, and lots of sugar. Refusing tea is considered rude.
Round flatbread, the staple of every Moroccan meal. Eaten with everything. Never thrown away — given to the poor or fed to animals.

examples.darija: Derna tajin dyal djaj bel7amed w zitun
examples.arabic: درنا طاجين ديال دجاج بلحامض و زيتون
examples.english: We made chicken tagine with lemon and olives
examples.french: On a fait un tajine de poulet au citron et olives

cultural_note: Both the conical clay pot and the slow-cooked dish made in it. The most iconic Moroccan dish.
The Friday staple. Families gather for couscous every Friday after prayer. It's steamed semolina with vegetables and meat.
Moroccan coffee is usually 'noss noss' (half coffee, half milk) or strong black espresso.
The most popular coffee order in Morocco. Half coffee, half steamed milk. Order 'wahd noss noss' at any café.

examples.french: On a fait du poulet chermoula

examples.english: Fish in Essaouira is very delicious
examples.french: Le poisson à Essaouira est très bon

cultural_note: In Darija, '7ut' means fish in general. In MSA, it specifically means 'whale'.

examples.french: Les fruits sont chers cette semaine

cultural_note: Olive oil is central to Moroccan cuisine. Used for cooking, dipping bread, and even beauty treatments.
Moroccans use A LOT of sugar in their tea. Don't be surprised.

examples.french: On a fait des œufs aux tomates

cultural_note: Borrowed from Spanish/French. Darija is full of European loanwords for food.

examples.french: Mets du beurre sur le pain

examples.english: Do you cook with smen or butter?
examples.french: Tu cuisines avec du smen ou du beurre ?

cultural_note: Fermented and aged salted butter. A prized ingredient in Moroccan cooking. Can be aged for years. Very strong flavor.
Buttery, flaky, layered flatbread. A breakfast staple. Often filled with meat, cheese, or khlii.

examples.english: Beghrir with honey and butter, mmmm
examples.french: Beghrir au miel et beurre, mmmm

cultural_note: Spongy semolina pancakes with tiny holes that soak up honey and butter. Breakfast or Ramadan favorite.

examples.french: La harira pendant le Ramadan, c'est incomparable

cultural_note: THE Ramadan soup. Rich tomato-based soup with lentils, chickpeas, vermicelli. Eaten to break the fast at sunset.

examples.darija: Lpastilla dyal l7ut wlla dyal djaj?
examples.arabic: لبسطيلة ديال الحوت ولا ديال الدجاج؟
examples.french: Pastilla au poisson ou au poulet ?

cultural_note: Flaky phyllo pie traditionally with pigeon, almonds, cinnamon, and sugar. Sweet and savory at once. A royal dish.

examples.english: We made rfissa because the bride came
examples.french: On a fait de la rfissa car la mariée est venue

cultural_note: Shredded msemmen layered with lentils, chicken, and fenugreek. Traditionally served to new mothers to help recovery.

examples.darija: Ltanjia hiya l akla dyal Marrakech
examples.english: Tanjia is the dish of Marrakech
examples.french: La tanjia est le plat de Marrakech

cultural_note: A Marrakech specialty. Meat seasoned with spices, sealed in a clay pot, and slow-cooked in the ashes of a hammam furnace for hours.
Whole lamb slow-roasted until tender. Served at celebrations. The meat falls off the bone.

examples.french: Le miel du désert est cher

cultural_note: Morocco is one of the world's top olive producers. Olives appear at every meal.

examples.french: Des pois chiches dans la harira

cultural_note: The Darija word for delicious. 'Bnin bzzaf!' is the best compliment you can give a Moroccan cook.

examples.french: Le petit déjeuner est bon aujourd'hui

cultural_note: Moroccan breakfast is elaborate: bread, msemmen, beghrir, honey, olive oil, cheese, jam, tea, coffee.

examples.english: What are we making for lunch?
examples.french: Qu'est-ce qu'on fait pour le déjeuner ?
Le dîner est à huit heures

examples.darija: Dir shwiya dyal ras l7anut f ttajin
examples.arabic: دير شوية ديال راس الحانوت ف الطاجين
examples.english: Put some ras el hanout in the tagine
examples.french: Mets un peu de ras el hanout dans le tajine

cultural_note: Literally 'head of the shop' — the spice merchant's signature blend. Can contain 20-30 different spices. Every merchant has their own recipe.
The most used spice in Moroccan cooking. Present in almost every dish.

examples.french: Le gingembre est bon pour la santé
Mets du curcuma dans le bouillon

cultural_note: Preserved lemons are essential to Moroccan cooking, especially in tagines. Fresh lemon juice goes in everything.

examples.french: Je veux du thé à la menthe

cultural_note: Fresh spearmint is essential for Moroccan tea. Sold in huge bunches at every market.

examples.french: Ajoute de la coriandre et du persil

cultural_note: Used fresh in enormous quantities in Moroccan cooking. Chermoula marinade is based on it.

examples.english: Here you go, rice with chicken

cultural_note: Thin noodles used in harira and couscous dishes.

examples.french: On a frit des pommes de terre
Mets des carottes dans le tajine
Le zaalouk est bon avec du pain

cultural_note: Smoky eggplant and tomato dip/salad. A Moroccan mezze staple, eaten with bread.

examples.french: Marine le poisson avec de la chermoula

cultural_note: Marinade of cilantro, parsley, garlic, cumin, paprika, lemon. Used on fish and meat. Every family has their own version.

examples.french: La harira de ma mère est délicieuse

examples.english: Amlou from the Souss is the best
examples.french: L'amlou du Souss est le meilleur

cultural_note: A thick paste of almonds, argan oil, and honey. From the Souss region. The Amazigh 'Nutella'. Eaten with bread at breakfast.

examples.french: Œufs au khlii, petit déjeuner marocain

cultural_note: Sun-dried spiced meat preserved in fat. Made after Eid al-Adha. The Moroccan equivalent of jerky/confit.

examples.darija: Lbriwat b ljbn wlla b lluz?
examples.french: Briouates au fromage ou aux amandes ?

cultural_note: Triangle or cigar-shaped fried pastries. Filled with meat, cheese, or almonds. Festive food and Ramadan favorite.

examples.darija: Jib shlada dyal tomatish w bsal
examples.arabic: جيب شلاضة ديال طماطيش و بصل
examples.french: Apporte une salade de tomates et oignons

cultural_note: Moroccan 'salads' are often cooked — roasted peppers, tomato dips, zaalouk. Served as a starter in small dishes.
Thick round semolina bread, denser than khobz. Often baked in communal ovens (ferran).

examples.english: Go to the oven, bring bread
examples.french: Va au four, ramène le pain

cultural_note: The neighborhood bread oven where families send their dough to be baked. A social institution in the medina.
The traditional market. Every Moroccan city has souks organized by trade — spice souk, leather souk, carpet souk, etc.

examples.english: Go to the shop, bring sugar
examples.french: Va à l'épicerie, ramène du sucre

cultural_note: The neighborhood corner store. Sells everything from bread to phone credit. Open late. Every derb has at least one.
From 'fulūs' (small coins). In Darija, it means money in general.

examples.english: What's the price of these shoes?
examples.french: Quel est le prix de ces chaussures ?

examples.english: Lower the price for me a bit!
I want to buy a carpet
How much are you selling this for?

examples.french: Le tapis de l'Atlas est beau

cultural_note: Moroccan carpets are world-famous. Expect theatrical bargaining when buying one.

examples.french: Je veux un sac en cuir

cultural_note: Fes is famous for its tanneries. Moroccan leather goods — bags, shoes, belts — are a top souvenir.
The Moroccan currency. 1 EUR ≈ 10-11 MAD. Locals sometimes quote prices in riyals (1 riyal = 5 centimes), which is confusing.
An old currency unit still used in souks. 20 riyals = 1 dirham. If someone says '200 riyal' they mean 10 dirhams. Very confusing for tourists!

examples.english: I want a pair of these shoes
examples.french: Je veux une paire de ces chaussures

examples.english: Give me a kilo of tomatoes
Go to the spice merchant, bring cumin
examples.french: Va chez l'épicier, ramène du cumin

cultural_note: The traditional herbalist and spice merchant. Sells spices, herbs, natural remedies, and cosmetics.

examples.english: Where can I get a taxi?
examples.french: Où est-ce que je prends un taxi ?

cultural_note: Two types: petit taxi (within city, by meter — in theory) and grand taxi (between cities, shared). Always negotiate!

examples.darija: Ltran ghadi ykhrj f ss3a ts3ud
examples.arabic: التران غادي يخرج ف الساعة تسعود

examples.darija: Sir nishaan, w mn b3d dwr 3la lisir
examples.arabic: سير نيشان، و من بعد دور على اليسير
examples.french: Va tout droit, puis tourne à gauche
Non, c'est proche, vas-y à pied

examples.english: I went to work by bicycle
examples.french: Je suis allé au travail en vélo

examples.english: Take me to the station, please
examples.french: Emmène-moi à la gare, s'il te plaît

examples.english: I want to go to the old medina
examples.french: Je veux aller à la médina

cultural_note: The historic walled city center. Narrow winding streets, souks, riads. The heart of every Moroccan city.
The narrow streets of the medina. Used for addresses: 'zanqa X, derb Y'.
A small residential alley in the medina, or the neighborhood it defines. The basic unit of medina social life.

examples.english: The taxi is at Bab Doukkala
examples.french: Le taxi est à Bab Doukkala

cultural_note: The monumental gates of Moroccan cities: Bab Agnaou, Bab Doukkala, etc. Used for navigation.
In Darija, 'tani' also commonly means 'also/too/again'.
Intimate Darija word for mother.
Also used for any close male friend.
Also used to address any woman warmly.
Means both woman and wife.
Also a friendly term for older men.
Used to address older women warmly.
Can last 3-7 days.
Respectful for any woman.
Respectful for any man.
Both house and home in Darija.
More common than MSA 'ghadban'.
Means both tired and sick.
Means both love and want!
Powerful social concept.
Used for sympathy.
Very commonly used.
Past tense is base form. 'Mshit'=I went.
More common than MSA 'takallam'.
Darija uses 'shaf' not MSA 'ra2a'.
Means both read and study.
Expresses both wanting and loving.
'Shno jra?'=What happened?
'Sdd lbab'=close the door.
House with interior courtyard.
From French.
For laundry and sunsets.
Both blessing and enough!

french: que Dieu ait pitié de lui
que Dieu te donne la santé

english: may God complete you with goodness

french: il n'y a de pouvoir que Dieu

english: I want to borrow a phone

french: que Dieu te donne le bien

english: may God fill it with you
french: que Dieu la remplisse de toi

english: God keep you for your parents
french: Dieu te garde pour tes parents

english: I want to book a room

french: il n'y a de dieu que Dieu

cultural_note: The ritual pouring from height to create foam.
Actually a mix of avocado, milk, and nuts. The name is just dramatic.
Made of toasted flour, almonds, sesame, butter, honey. Ramadan essential.
The essential Moroccan fish marinade: cilantro, garlic, cumin, paprika, lemon.
Used to describe low-quality imitation products.
Religious brotherhood lodges. Important in Moroccan spiritual life.
The pre-wedding henna party. Women gather for henna, music, and sweets.
Sacred in Morocco. Turning away a guest brings shame.
Traditional in the Rif mountains. Different cultural status than in the West.
Shared Mercedes taxis between cities. Fixed routes, fixed prices, leave when full.
The most prized saffron in the world, from the Taliouine region of Morocco.
Endemic to Morocco. The goats climb these trees.
Prized wood from Essaouira region. Used for marquetry and furniture.

english: nobody could do what you do
may God count it among your good deeds
french: que Dieu le compte parmi tes bonnes actions
